discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Expose is for exposing a port to the internet by way of a public ip. Apply and create make new things with the big difference being that create will fail if the resource already exists and apply will update the resource based on the Yaml.

comments.content:
Oops, it has "expose" as well

If the pods or deployments are already there and he wants to deploy a new service, A and E should be correct.

discussion.content:
A and D
The kubectl command has "apply" and "create" only, I think...

questions.question_text: A user wants to deploy a new service to a Kubernetes cluster. Which two commands accomplish this goal? (Choose two.)

A developer wants to deploy a highly available web server cluster and decides to put a load balancer in front of multiple clustered nodes that run the same web service. The goal is for the load balancer to take in users and distribute the load across the whole cluster.
What kind of high-availability configuration is the developer running?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Active active is correct.

Selected Answer: D
Distribute the load means Active-Active, so D

questions.question_text:
A developer has created a deployment that should launch a pod to run their database service. The pod should launch with a metadata name of "Cisco-DB," and the developer has added it to the "Cisco" namespace in their deployment.
Which Kubernetes command confirms that the service is running and usable?

discussion.content: By "service" the question means its not kind: Service Kubernetes object but service (process) in general. You can only see it if pod is running, By investigating kind: Service on Kubernetes cluster you won't be able to deduct if the service is operational, you'll only see how the IP is exposed.

questions.question_text: Which step must be taken to enable centralized logging in a Kubernetes environment?

comments.content:
agree with D:
 Some typical uses of a DaemonSet are:
running a cluster storage daemon on every node
running a logs collection daemon on every node
running a node monitoring daemon on every node

discussion.content: Answer is D: a sidecar is a container and not a node, hence C is wrong.

Selected Answer: D
https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/cluster-administration/logging/#cluster-level-logging-architectures
"""
Because the logging agent must run on every node, it is recommended to run the agent as a DaemonSet.
"""

choices.A: No steps need to be taken. The master node automatically aggregates logs from all worker nodes and stores them on the specified persistent volume.
choices.D: Create a DaemonSet that deploys a container with a logging agent on every node in the cluster.
choices.B: Create a CustomResourceDefinition in each deployment that specifies the IP or names the log collector.
choices.C: Deploy a sidecar node that aggregates logs from the entire cluster.

discussion.content: I think D, such as Prometheus

questions.question_text: Which interface is most commonly used to integrate logging, monitoring, and alerting applications into your CI/CD pipeline?
